pullrequest.title: Generic physics parameters in Gazebo and SDF

content.raw:
Oh, good to know.

If I'm reading this right, I was mistaken originally about protobuf versions packaged for ubuntu:

* [trusty: 2.5.0](http://packages.ubuntu.com/trusty/libdevel/libprotobuf-dev)
* [utopic: 2.5.0](http://packages.ubuntu.com/utopic/libdevel/libprotobuf-dev)
* [vivd: 2.6.1](http://packages.ubuntu.com/vivid/libdevel/libprotobuf-dev)

2.6.1 is available from a PPA in trusty, of course. But I have a feeling the protobuf team does not plan on releasing official debs for 2.6.1 in trusty or utopic. 

I'm not sure what to do about versioning. The implementation would be a lot cleaner if I could use these newer protobuf features right away in Gazebo 6. But then to install Gazebo in trusty and utopic, the user has to install a custom protobuf 2.6 library (something that we package or we give them through the PPA). Could that have cross-compatibility issues with other applications?

I also don't know how to implement this in a way that's cross compatible with Protobuf 2.5 and 2.6. You can't `#ifdef PROTOBUF_2.6` in a protobuf message declaration...
content.html:
Oh, good to know.

If I'm reading this right, I was mistaken originally about protobuf versions packaged for ubuntu:

  • trusty: 2.5.0
  • utopic: 2.5.0
  • vivd: 2.6.1

2.6.1 is available from a PPA in trusty, of course. But I have a feeling the protobuf team does not plan on releasing official debs for 2.6.1 in trusty or utopic.

I'm not sure what to do about versioning. The implementation would be a lot cleaner if I could use these newer protobuf features right away in Gazebo 6. But then to install Gazebo in trusty and utopic, the user has to install a custom protobuf 2.6 library (something that we package or we give them through the PPA). Could that have cross-compatibility issues with other applications?

I also don't know how to implement this in a way that's cross compatible with Protobuf 2.5 and 2.6. You can't #ifdef PROTOBUF_2.6 in a protobuf message declaration...
